definitions: cry out in grief or pain with long high-pitched sounds expressing deep sorrow
examples: The mother wailed when she heard the terrible news
Babies often wail when they need attention from parents

definitions: voluntarily give up a right or claim to something you are entitled to
officially decide not to enforce a rule or requirement in a particular case
examples: She waived her right to a lawyer during questioning
The defendant waived his claim to the disputed property
The school waived the entrance fee for scholarship students
The bank waived the overdraft charges as a courtesy

definitions: strike someone or something with great force using hand or object
examples: The boxer walloped his opponent with a powerful right hook
The storm walloped the coastal towns with hurricane-force winds

definitions: apply decorative paper to walls of a room as covering or decoration
examples: They decided to wallpaper the bedroom with a floral pattern
We spent the weekend wallpapering the nursery for the baby

definitions: dance to music in three-quarter time with a partner in circular movements
move somewhere easily and confidently as if without effort or concern
examples: The couple waltzed gracefully across the ballroom floor
They learned to waltz for their wedding reception dance
She just waltzed into the office and demanded a raise
He waltzed through the exam without studying at all

definitions: gradually decrease in size amount intensity or degree over time
examples: His enthusiasm for the project began to wane after months
The moon wanes after reaching its full phase each month

definitions: guard or protect someone or something from danger harm or attack
examples: She raised her hands to ward off the attacker
They hung garlic to ward off evil spirits from home

definitions: store goods or merchandise in a large building designed for storage
examples: The company warehouses its products before distributing them nationwide
They warehouse seasonal items until the right selling time arrives

definitions: become bent or twisted out of normal shape especially from heat or dampness
cause something to become distorted biased or different from normal truth
examples: The wooden floor warped after the flooding damaged the house
Heat from the sun can warp vinyl records left in cars
Years of propaganda warped their perception of the outside world
Childhood trauma can warp a person's view of relationships

definitions: create artwork using paints that are mixed with water before applying
examples: She loves to watercolor landscapes during her weekend trips
The artist watercolored a beautiful portrait of her grandmother

definitions: create artwork using paints that are mixed with water before applying
examples: He learned to watercolour at the local community art center
The children watercoloured pictures of flowers in art class today

definitions: treat something with substances to prevent water from passing through or damaging it
examples: We need to waterproof the deck before the rainy season
The company waterproofs all its outdoor gear before selling it

definitions: move in a quivering way or flicker unsteadily back and forth
become unsteady in purpose or action showing doubt or indecision
examples: The candle flame wavered in the gentle breeze from window
His voice wavered with emotion as he gave the speech
She never wavered in her commitment to helping the poor
His confidence began to waver when he saw the competition

definitions: apply a wax substance to something for protection shine or smoothness
gradually increase in size number strength or intensity over time
examples: She waxes her car every month to keep it shiny
The salon waxed her legs to remove unwanted hair completely
The moon waxes until it becomes full each lunar month
His enthusiasm for the project waxed as success became apparent

definitions: make or become less strong in physical strength power or effectiveness
examples: The illness weakened his immune system considerably over several months
Constant criticism can weaken a child's self-confidence and motivation

definitions: cause someone to feel extremely tired especially from prolonged effort or endurance
examples: The long hike through the mountains wearied all the climbers
Constant complaints from customers can weary even patient employees

definitions: form fabric by interlacing long threads passing in one direction with others at right angles
move along by passing in and out between obstacles or changing direction repeatedly
examples: She learned to weave baskets from her grandmother's teachings
The factory weaves beautiful silk fabrics for expensive clothing
The motorcycle weaved through heavy traffic to reach the hospital
The drunk driver was weaving dangerously across all three lanes

definitions: marry someone in a formal ceremony making them husband or wife
examples: They plan to wed in a small ceremony next spring
The prince will wed his longtime girlfriend at the cathedral

definitions: force something into a narrow space between two things or surfaces
examples: He wedged the door open with a piece of wood
She wedged herself between two people on the crowded train

definitions: pass urine from the body in an informal or childish way
examples: The toddler needs to wee before we leave the house
The puppy weed on the carpet during house training yesterday

definitions: shed tears as an expression of strong emotion especially sadness or grief
examples: She wept openly at her father's funeral service last week
The movie was so touching that many viewers wept

definitions: join pieces of metal together by heating surfaces to melting point and pressing together
examples: The mechanic welded the broken exhaust pipe back together
Factory workers weld car parts on the assembly line daily

definitions: hit someone or something with a sharp blow using hand or implement
examples: He whacked the ball over the fence for a home run
She whacked the pi√±ata until candy spilled out everywhere

definitions: hit something with great force producing a loud sound on impact
examples: The car whammed into the concrete barrier at high speed
He whammed his fist on the table to emphasize his point

definitions: get a brief smell or scent of something passing by quickly
fail to hit something especially when swinging at a ball
examples: I whiffed the delicious aroma coming from the bakery
She whiffed perfume as the woman walked past her
The batter whiffed at three straight pitches and struck out
He whiffed the golf ball completely on his first attempt

definitions: complain in a feeble or petulant way with a high-pitched voice
examples: The child whined about having to go to bed early
Stop whining about the homework and just finish it already

definitions: move or cause to move rapidly around and around on an axis
examples: The dancers whirled across the stage in colorful costumes
The helicopter blades whirled faster as it prepared for takeoff

definitions: produce a clear high-pitched sound by forcing breath through pursed lips
examples: He whistled a cheerful tune while walking to work
The referee whistled to stop play when someone was injured

definitions: paint something white using a mixture of lime and water or white paint
deliberately conceal mistakes or faults to present something as better than reality
examples: They whitewashed the old fence to make it look new
We need to whitewash the basement walls before moving in
The company tried to whitewash the scandal with false reports
The investigation was just a whitewash to protect the officials

definitions: carve wood into an object by repeatedly cutting small slices from it
examples: My grandfather would whittle wooden toys for all the grandchildren
He sat on the porch whittling a walking stick from oak

definitions: move very quickly through the air making a humming or buzzing sound
examples: Cars whizzed past us on the busy highway during rush hour
The arrow whizzed by his head missing him by mere inches

definitions: sell goods in large quantities to retailers rather than individual consumers
examples: The company wholesales furniture to stores across the entire country
They wholesale imported electronics at competitive prices to retailers

definitions: give a loud cry of joy excitement or triumph with enthusiasm
examples: The crowd whooped with delight when their team scored
Children whooped and hollered on the last day of school

definitions: work as a prostitute exchanging sexual acts for money or goods
examples: Some people are forced to whore due to desperate circumstances
The novel depicts characters who whore to survive in poverty

definitions: make or become greater in width or extent from side to side
examples: The city plans to widen the road to reduce traffic
Her eyes widened in surprise when she heard the news

definitions: cause someone to become a widow or widower by death of spouse
examples: The war widowed thousands of women across the country
She was widowed at thirty when her husband died suddenly

definitions: hold and use a weapon or tool with hands in effective way
examples: The knight wielded his sword with great skill in battle
She wields considerable influence in the business community these days

definitions: move up and down or from side to side with small rapid movements
examples: The puppy wiggled its tail excitedly when we came home
She wiggled her toes in the warm sand at the beach

definitions: become limp and droop as a result of heat or loss of water
examples: The flowers wilted quickly in the hot afternoon sun
Without water the lettuce leaves wilted within just two days

definitions: lift or pull something using a machine with rope or chain wound around drum
examples: They winched the boat out of the water for repairs
The rescue team winched the injured hiker up to the helicopter

definitions: close and open one eye quickly as a signal or greeting to someone
examples: She winked at her friend across the crowded room
The grandfather winked at his grandson before telling a joke

definitions: secretly listen to telephone conversations by connecting recording equipment to phone lines
examples: The FBI got permission to wiretap the suspect's phone
It's illegal to wiretap someone without proper court authorization

definitions: become dry and shriveled from age heat or loss of moisture
examples: The crops withered during the long summer drought last year
Her hopes withered when she received the rejection letter

definitions: refuse to give something that is due or desired keeping it back deliberately
examples: The company illegally withheld wages from its workers
She decided to withhold the truth until the right moment

definitions: remain strong and undamaged despite facing difficult conditions or attacks
examples: The building was designed to withstand earthquake tremors
She withstood years of criticism but never gave up trying

definitions: move unsteadily from side to side with irregular rocking motion
examples: The table wobbles because one leg is shorter than others
He wobbled on the bicycle before gaining his balance

definitions: try to gain the love of someone through romantic gestures or attention
examples: He wooed her with flowers and romantic dinners for months
The prince traveled far to woo the beautiful princess

definitions: move with difficulty by crawling or wriggling like a worm does
examples: The soldier wormed through the narrow tunnel to reach safety
She wormed her way through the crowd to the front

definitions: make or become worse in quality condition or situation than before
examples: The patient's condition worsened overnight requiring immediate surgery
Adding more salt will only worsen the taste of the soup
